Book Review: “Remote: Office Not Required”

I recently read Remote: Office Not Required by Jason Fried and David Heinemeier Hansson. I thought it’d be great to see if I was working remotely the right way and pick up tips to improve if I wasn’t. I’ll be sharing a few thoughts from the book in this article. The two most important things which stood out to me and constantly reoccurred throughout all the chapters, sometimes indirectly, were trust and communication. Our entire software team is structured around these as we don’t have constant remote surveillance. Everyone trusts the other to show up everyday and pick up the phone.

First chapter: The time is right for remote work

All the benefits of remote work were listed here e.g. The time and money saved from no/less commute, the opportunity for employees to live and work from anywhere while living their dreams, companies’ access to talent from any part of the world while saving money at the same time.

I already knew what came with the package so there were no surprises here. All the points I listed above were the good parts though. A few aspects of remote work are not so rosy. It’s not quite easy getting used to not seeing coworkers in person, a lot of personal discipline is required and a dedicated room for work is recommended. I’m sure I have more challenges with a good internet connection and stable power supply than a remote worker from another part of the world because, Nigeria. 😞

Second chapter: Dealing with excuses

Although very relevant, this chapter didn’t speak to me. It lists all the excuses companies might have against remote work. I felt there was no need to sell remote work to me/my company since they already practice it heavily.

They know that magic doesn’t need to happen only when people are in the same room. They know the value of flying people in together at least once a year. We have a lot of different tools for communication and they know talent isn’t bound by hubs.

Third chapter: How to collaborate remotely

Annyce and I are the only Android developers and we have a five-hour time difference between us. To be able to achieve overlap hours, I sometimes start work by 10 AM or 11 AM my time. All my meetings happen in the late afternoon and evening so I usually leave the mornings for focus work.

Work from home, they said :)

Some of our collaboration tools include Github, Jira, Slack, Google Calendar and Drive, Dropbox, Zeplin, Marvel and Zoom.

My typical workday starts by checking my calendar for any meetings. I note the times if there are any and start preparing or start thinking about items I might need. I also check Slack for any conversations from the previous day and respond to all that need my attention. Next, I check Github for any pending PRs. I usually take my time with this, but I always aim to review them before Annyce starts her own day so that I’m not a blocker. I then do a Standup with Geekbot on Slack and start work.

Fourth chapter: Beware the dragons

Cabin fever is real. My longest streak for being cooped up indoors is seven days. To combat this, I sometimes join a local running group. I also change my location and work from a coffee shop instead.

There are a lot of chances of overworking especially when no commute is required. When this happens, they think it’s best for me to decide if I have achieved a good day’s work and stop at that point.

Fifth chapter: Hiring and keeping the best

I used to have a lot of anxiety about my work when I first joined and some things took longer than necessary. Even a one-liner change required knowing which exact file to change, understanding what code structure already exists and following that with every PR submitted. I became more familiar with the codebase as time went on.

The tone of messages, especially in code reviews is very important here and I think Annyce should win a medal for this. Don’t you think comments would come off as non-accusatory when we rephrase them as questions?

Sixth chapter: Managing remote workers

OGE knows the value of bringing all the team members together and I was really bummed that I missed the opportunity to meet all the members of my team at a company conference recently. It’s definitely great that I meet up with Annyce at conferences now. 😁

It also helps that I follow some of my colleagues on social media. It exposes a bit of their personality outside of Slack. One-on-ones also help. Mine is a chance for my manager to catch up with what’s happening with me.

Seventh chapter: Life as a remote worker

I actually don’t feel like working on some days. I usually change my environment and work from somewhere different instead. Or, I just start and trust that I’ll get into the flow soon enough. On other days, I can’t stop thinking of work and can’t wait to get back to it. That’s where the danger of overworking lies.

The authors wrote about having a daily routine but I don’t have that. I only have a different room for work although I work from my bed on days I decide not to adult. 🤷🏽‍

Conclusion

I think this book was a good read and it did a great job of highlighting all the things to know about remote work. Have you read Remote? Do you work remotely from Nigeria or some other part of the world? I’d love to hear your thoughts in the comments below.
